sections.title: What You'll Learn
items: What a marginal bracket actually means
Why your whole income is not taxed at your top rate
How deductions and credits reduce taxes differently
Simple moves to improve after‑tax income

sections.title: Marginal vs. Effective
sections.content: The U.S. uses progressive brackets: the first slice of income is taxed at the lowest rate, the next slice at a higher rate, and so on. Your marginal rate applies only to the last dollars you earn. Your effective rate is total tax divided by total income—almost always much lower than the top bracket you hear about.

points.title: Deductions
points.description: Reduce taxable income (e.g., standard deduction, retirement contributions). Value depends on your marginal rate.

points.title: Credits
points.description: Directly reduce tax bill dollar‑for‑dollar (e.g., child tax credit). Generally more powerful than deductions.

sections.title: Bracket Creep
sections.content: Small raises can push part of your income into the next bracket. Use pre‑tax contributions (HSA/401(k)) or Roth strategy to manage.

sections.title: Quick Wins This Year
steps: Estimate your marginal rate and decide whether pre‑tax or Roth contributions make more sense.
If eligible, contribute to an HSA—it's triple tax advantaged.
Bunch deductible expenses (like charitable gifts) into one year to beat the standard deduction.
Review withholding using the IRS estimator to avoid a surprise tax bill.

sections.title: Plan in November, Not April
sections.content: Tax planning is proactive. Adjust contributions and deductions before year‑end so April becomes a formality, not a firefight.
